domains.text: Custom list of email domains to randomly choose from. Use JSON list format. Leave empty to use realistic default domains (gmail.com, yahoo.com, outlook.com, etc.)
domains.example: Empty: foretime10@live.com, user123@gmail.com, sarah@yahoo.com (diverse domains) | ["company.com", "business.org"]: user@company.com, john@business.org (your domains only) | ["gmail.com", "yahoo.com", "outlook.com"]: popular email providers only

unique.text: Toggle ON to guarantee all email addresses are unique (no duplicates). Toggle OFF to allow duplicate emails. IMPORTANT: When ON, each row gets a completely unique email address
unique.example: OFF: may generate duplicates like user@gmail.com, user@gmail.com (same email twice) | ON: guarantees all different like user1@gmail.com, user2@yahoo.com, user3@outlook.com (all unique) | Recommended: ON for user databases, OFF for general testing

gender.text: Choose 'Mixed (Random)' for realistic datasets with both male and female names, or select a specific gender for all rows
Choose 'Mixed (Random)' to get both male and female first names in your dataset. Gender determines the name pool for each row.
gender.example: Mixed (Random) gives: John, Sarah, Michael, Emily...

gender.text: Choose 'Mixed (Random)' for diverse names. In some locales, last names may vary by gender.
Choose 'Mixed (Random)' (recommended) to generate realistic datasets with both male and female names
gender.example: Mixed gives: John Smith, Sarah Johnson, Michael Brown...

reverse.text: Toggle ON to reverse the name order (Last Name, First Name). Toggle OFF for standard order (First Name Last Name). Useful for different cultural naming conventions or formal listings
reverse.example: OFF: John Smith, Sarah Johnson, Michael Brown, Emily Davis (First Last) | ON: Smith John, Johnson Sarah, Brown Michael, Davis Emily (Last First) | Use ON for: formal lists, Asian naming conventions, alphabetical sorting by last name

gender.text: Choose 'Mixed (Random)' for realistic datasets with both male and female names
Choose 'Mixed (Random)' to get both Mr./Mrs./Ms. titles matching the generated names

max_year.text: Maximum birth year (must be >= 1900 and <= current year)

start.text: Start year for date generation (must be a year number)

end.text: End year for date generation (must be a year number)

start.text: Start year for datetime generation (must be a year number)

end.text: End year for datetime generation (must be a year number)

timezone.text: Select a timezone for datetime generation. Choose 'None' to use default system timezone
timezone.example: Popular choices: UTC (universal), America/New_York (US Eastern), Europe/London (UK), Asia/Tokyo (Japan)

fmt.text: Date format template using strftime codes. Leave empty to use locale default format
Datetime format template using strftime codes. Leave empty to use locale default format
Time format template using strftime codes. Leave empty to use locale default format

start.text: Minimum integer value (inclusive) - the lowest number that can be generated
start.example: 1 generates integers starting from 1 | -100 allows negative integers from -100 | 0 includes zero and positive numbers

end.text: Maximum integer value (inclusive) - the highest number that can be generated
end.example: 100 generates integers up to 100 | 1000 for larger numbers | -1 with start=-100 generates only negative integers

start.text: Minimum integer value (inclusive) - the lowest number that can be generated. Default is -1000
start.example: 0 for non-negative integers | 1 for positive integers only | -100 allows negative numbers from -100

end.text: Maximum integer value (inclusive) - the highest number that can be generated. Default is 1000
end.example: 100 for integers up to 100 | 1000000 for large numbers | -1 with start=-100 for only negative integers

start.text: Minimum float value (inclusive) - the lowest decimal number that can be generated. Default is -1000.0
start.example: 0.0 for non-negative decimals | 0.5 starts from half | -100.5 allows negative decimals

end.text: Maximum float value (inclusive) - the highest decimal number that can be generated. Default is 1000.0
end.example: 100.0 for decimals up to 100 | 1.0 with start=0.0 for values between 0 and 1 | 999.99 for prices

precision.text: Number of decimal places (digits after the decimal point). Default is 15. Controls how precise the decimal number is

start.text: Minimum decimal value (inclusive) - for high-precision financial calculations. Default is -1000.0
start.example: 0.0 for non-negative amounts | 0.01 for monetary values (avoiding zero) | -1000.0 for accounting (positive and negative)

end.text: Maximum decimal value (inclusive) - for high-precision financial calculations. Default is 1000.0
end.example: 1000000.0 for large transactions | 9999.99 for prices | 100.0 for percentages as decimals

start_real.text: Minimum value for the real part (the 'a' in a+bi). Real part is the non-imaginary component of complex numbers
start_real.example: -10.0 allows negative real parts | 0.0 for non-negative real parts | -100.0 for wide range

end_real.text: Maximum value for the real part (the 'a' in a+bi). Sets the upper limit for the real component
end_real.example: 10.0 gives real parts up to 10 | 100.0 for larger range | 0.0 with start=-10.0 for only negative real parts

start_imag.text: Minimum value for the imaginary part (the 'b' in a+bi). Imaginary part is the coefficient of 'i' (‚àö-1)
start_imag.example: -10.0 allows negative imaginary parts | 0.0 for non-negative | -5.0 for moderate range

end_imag.text: Maximum value for the imaginary part (the 'b' in a+bi). Sets the upper limit for the imaginary component
end_imag.example: 10.0 gives imaginary parts up to 10 | 5.0 for smaller range | 100.0 for wide range

precision_real.text: Number of decimal places for the real part. Default is 15. Controls precision of the real component

precision_imag.text: Number of decimal places for the imaginary part. Default is 15. Controls precision of the imaginary component

accumulator.text: Optional unique identifier for independent counter sequences. Each accumulator maintains its own separate counter. Leave empty for a default global counter. All counters start at 1
accumulator.example: Empty (default): 1, 2, 3, 4, 5... | With 'user_id': starts at 1 (independent) | With 'order_id': also starts at 1 (independent) | Example: Empty‚Üí1, 'a'‚Üí1, Empty‚Üí2, 'a'‚Üí2, 'b'‚Üí1, 'a'‚Üí3 (each accumulator counts separately)

items.text: List of items to randomly choose from

elements.text: List of elements for random selection

quantity.text: Number of random words to generate. Returns a list of words. Perfect for testing word lists, tags, keywords, or multi-word fields
quantity.example: 1 gives: ["hello"] | 3 gives: ["hello", "world", "test"] | 5 gives: ["lorem", "ipsum", "dolor", "sit", "amet"] | 10 generates a list of 10 random words

quantity.text: Number of sentences or paragraphs to generate in the text block. Creates coherent text content for testing
quantity.example: 1 gives single sentence/paragraph | 3 gives 3 sentences/paragraphs | 5 gives longer text block with 5 units | Used for: article content, descriptions, comments

low.text: Minimum value (inclusive) - lower boundary of the uniform distribution. All values between low and high are equally likely
low.example: 0.0 with high=1.0 generates values between 0 and 1 | 10.0 with high=100.0 generates values between 10 and 100 | -5.0 with high=5.0 generates values between -5 and 5

high.text: Maximum value (exclusive) - upper boundary of the uniform distribution. The actual maximum generated will be slightly less than this value
high.example: 1.0 with low=0.0 generates ~0.0 to ~0.999 | 100.0 with low=10.0 generates ~10.0 to ~99.999 | 5.0 with low=-5.0 generates ~-5.0 to ~4.999

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

a.text: Lower boundary of the output interval (inclusive)

b.text: Upper boundary of the output interval (exclusive)

loc.text: Mean (average/center) of the normal distribution - the peak of the bell curve. Most values cluster around this number
loc.example: 0.0 centers around zero (standard normal) | 100.0 centers around 100 | 50.0 with scale=10 generates values mostly between 30-70

scale.text: Standard deviation (spread/width) of the distribution - controls how spread out values are. Larger scale = more spread. About 68% of values fall within ¬±1 scale from mean
scale.example: 1.0 with loc=0.0 is standard normal | 10.0 with loc=100 spreads values 80-120 typically | 0.5 creates tighter clustering around mean

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

n.text: Number of trials - how many times an event is attempted. Must be a positive integer. Think of it as flipping a coin 'n' times
n.example: 10 with p=0.5 simulates 10 coin flips (results 0-10) | 100 with p=0.1 simulates 100 trials with 10% success rate | 50 with p=0.3 gives ~15 successes on average

p.text: Probability of success for each trial (0.0 to 1.0). 0.5 = 50% chance, 0.1 = 10% chance, 0.9 = 90% chance
p.example: 0.5 with n=10 simulates fair coin (50/50) | 0.1 with n=100 expects ~10 successes | 0.7 with n=20 expects ~14 successes (high success rate)

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

lam.text: Lambda (Œª) - expected number of events/occurrences. This is both the mean and variance of the distribution. Common for counting rare events
lam.example: 5.0 expects ~5 events (generates mostly 3-7) | 1.0 for rare events (mostly 0-3) | 20.0 for frequent events (mostly 15-25) | Used for: customer arrivals, emails per hour, calls per day

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

scale.text: Scale parameter (1/Œª) - controls the rate of decay. Larger scale = events take longer. Used for time between events or waiting times
scale.example: 1.0 for average wait time of 1 unit | 0.5 for faster events (shorter waits) | 2.0 for slower events (longer waits) | Used for: time between arrivals, product lifetimes, service times

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

shape.text: Shape parameter (Œ±, alpha) - controls the shape of the distribution. Higher values make it more symmetric/normal-like. Must be > 0
shape.example: 1.0 gives exponential-like shape | 2.0 starts to look more bell-shaped | 9.0 approaches normal distribution | Used for: rainfall amounts, insurance claims, waiting times

scale.text: Scale parameter (Œ∏, theta) - stretches or compresses the distribution horizontally. Larger scale = larger values. Must be > 0
scale.example: 1.0 with shape=2.0 gives moderate values | 10.0 with shape=2.0 gives larger values | 0.5 with shape=2.0 gives smaller values

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

a.text: Alpha (Œ±) parameter - first shape parameter. Controls the distribution shape. Must be > 0. Higher Œ± shifts distribution right
a.example: 2.0 with b=2.0 creates symmetric bell around 0.5 | 0.5 with b=0.5 creates U-shape | 5.0 with b=2.0 shifts peak right | Used for: probabilities, percentages (0-1)

b.text: Beta (Œ≤) parameter - second shape parameter. Controls the distribution shape. Must be > 0. Higher Œ≤ shifts distribution left
b.example: 2.0 with a=2.0 creates symmetric bell around 0.5 | 2.0 with a=5.0 shifts peak left | 5.0 with a=2.0 creates right-skewed distribution

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

df.text: Degrees of freedom - must be a positive integer. Higher df makes distribution more symmetric and normal-like. Used in statistical hypothesis testing
df.example: 1 gives highly right-skewed distribution | 5 starts looking more symmetric | 30 approaches normal distribution | Used for: goodness-of-fit tests, variance testing

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

p.text: Probability of success (0.0 to 1.0) - the chance of success on each trial. Generates the number of trials needed to get first success
p.example: 0.5 expects 2 trials on average (50% success) | 0.1 expects 10 trials (10% success, rare event) | 0.9 expects ~1 trial (90% success, common event) | Used for: trials until first success

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

mean.text: Mean of the underlying normal distribution (not the mean of the lognormal itself). Controls the center of the log-transformed values
mean.example: 0.0 gives median around 1.0 | 1.0 shifts distribution higher | -1.0 shifts distribution lower | Used for: income, stock prices, file sizes

sigma.text: Standard deviation of the underlying normal distribution. Controls the spread. Larger sigma = more right-skewed and wider spread. Must be > 0
sigma.example: 0.5 creates moderate spread | 1.0 creates wider spread with longer tail | 0.25 creates tighter distribution | Used for: highly variable positive data

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

a.text: Shape parameter (Œ±, alpha) - controls how heavy the tail is. Smaller values = heavier tail (more extreme values). Must be > 0. The '80-20 rule' uses a‚âà1.16
a.example: 1.5 creates moderate power-law (80-20 type) | 3.0 creates lighter tail (less extreme values) | 1.0 creates very heavy tail (many extreme values) | Used for: wealth distribution, city sizes, word frequency

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

left.text: Left boundary (minimum value) - the lowest possible value in the distribution. Must be less than mode and right
left.example: 0.0 with mode=5.0, right=10.0 creates triangle from 0 to 10 peaked at 5 | 10.0 with mode=50.0, right=100.0 creates range 10-100

mode.text: Mode (peak/most likely value) - where the triangle peaks. Must be between left and right. Most values cluster around this number
mode.example: 5.0 with left=0.0, right=10.0 peaks in middle | 2.0 with left=0.0, right=10.0 peaks near left (left-skewed) | 8.0 with left=0.0, right=10.0 peaks near right (right-skewed)

right.text: Right boundary (maximum value) - the highest possible value in the distribution. Must be greater than left and mode
right.example: 10.0 with left=0.0, mode=5.0 creates range 0-10 | 100.0 with left=10.0, mode=50.0 creates range 10-100 | Used for: project estimates, cost modeling

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

a.text: Shape parameter (k) - controls the distribution shape. Must be > 0. a<1: decreasing failure rate, a=1: exponential (constant rate), a>1: increasing failure rate
a.example: 0.5 gives decreasing hazard (infant mortality) | 1.0 gives constant hazard (random failures) | 2.0 gives increasing hazard (wear-out) | 3.5 approaches normal | Used for: reliability, wind speed, survival analysis

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

mean.text: Mean of the distribution - the average value. Also called the drift rate. Must be > 0
mean.example: 1.0 centers distribution around 1 | 5.0 shifts peak to 5 | 0.5 creates distribution centered at 0.5 | Used for: decision times, first passage times

scale.text: Scale parameter (Œª, lambda) - controls the shape and spread. Higher scale = tighter distribution around mean. Must be > 0
scale.example: 1.0 with mean=1.0 creates moderate spread | 5.0 with mean=1.0 creates tighter clustering | 0.5 creates wider spread | Also called inverse Gaussian

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

a.text: Exponent parameter (Œ±, alpha) - controls how quickly probabilities decrease. Larger a = steeper decrease. Must be > 1. Follows Zipf's law: frequency ‚àù 1/rank^a
a.example: 1.5 moderate power law (like word frequency) | 2.0 steeper decline | 1.1 very gradual decline | Used for: word frequency, website popularity, city populations

size.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Auto-set to your row count! This parameter is automatically set to match the number of rows you're generating. You cannot change it
size.example: If you're generating 100 rows, size is automatically 100

code.text: Custom Python expression. Use 'request.row_number' for row index.

hashed.text: Toggle ON to generate bcrypt-hashed passwords, OFF for plain text

special_chars.text: Toggle ON to include special characters in passwords
special_chars.example: OFF: Abc123xyz, Pass456word | ON: Abc@123#xyz!, Pass$456&word*

digits.text: Toggle ON to include digits in passwords
digits.example: OFF: AbcDefGhi, PasswordTest | ON: Abc123Def, Pass456word

uppercase.text: Toggle ON to include uppercase letters in passwords
uppercase.example: OFF: abc123def, password456 | ON: Abc123Def, Password456

lowercase.text: Toggle ON to include lowercase letters in passwords
lowercase.example: OFF: ABC123DEF, PASSWORD456 | ON: Abc123Def, Password456

mask.text: Template pattern for username generation. Mask codes: C=Capitalized word, U=UPPERCASE word, l=lowercase word, d=digits (from drange). Separators: . _ - | Leave empty for simple lowercase name-based usernames
mask.example: Empty: john_smith, sarah_jones | mask='C_C_d': Cotte_Article_1923 | mask='U.l.d': ELKINS.wolverine.2013 | mask='l_l_d': plasmic_blockader_1907 | mask='C-d': Smith-2024 | mask='l.d': smith.2013

drang.text: Digit range as tuple (min, max) - controls the range of random digits when 'd' appears in mask. Format: (min, max) with parentheses and comma. Default is (1800, 2100)
drang.example: (1900, 2021) with mask='l_l_d' gives: plasmic_blockader_1907 | (2000, 2025) gives recent years: smith_jones_2024 | (1000, 9999) gives 4-digit numbers: user_name_5432 | (1, 99) gives 1-2 digits: username_42

gender.text: Choose 'Mixed (Random)' to generate usernames based on both male and female names

category.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse emojis from all categories, or select a specific category

file_type.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to generate diverse file types (images, videos, documents, audio)
Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get various file extensions, or select a specific file type
file_type.example: Mix gives diverse extensions across all file types

type_.text: MIME type category to generate. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' for diverse types across all categories
type_.example: APPLICATION: application/pdf, application/json | AUDIO: audio/mpeg, audio/wav | IMAGE: image/jpeg, image/png | VIDEO: video/mp4, video/webm | TEXT: text/html, text/plain | MESSAGE: message/rfc822

mime_type.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse MIME types (application, audio, image, video, text)
mime_type.example: Mix generates: application/pdf, audio/mpeg, image/jpeg, video/mp4, text/html, message/rfc822

card_type.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get all credit card types (Visa, MasterCard, Amex)
card_type.example: Mix generates realistic variety of card types

algorithm.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to generate hashes using different algorithms
algorithm.example: Mix gives: MD5, SHA256, SHA512, BLAKE2B, etc.

region.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get timezones from all regions globally
region.example: Mix gives: Africa/*, America/*, Europe/*, Asia/*, etc.

fmt.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to generate timestamps in different formats

scheme.text: URL protocol/scheme to use. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse URL schemes (http, https, ftp, etc.)
scheme.example: HTTP: http://example.com | HTTPS: https://example.com | FTP: ftp://files.example.com | Mix gives diverse schemes across all protocols

port_range.text: Port range for the URL. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get ports from all ranges (system, registered, dynamic)
port_range.example: WELL_KNOWN: http://example.com:80 or :443 | REGISTERED: http://example.com:8080 or :3000 | Mix gives diverse ports from all ranges

tld_type.text: Top-level domain type to use. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' for diverse TLDs (.com, .org, .uk, etc.)
tld_type.example: GTLD: http://example.com, http://example.org | CCTLD: http://example.uk, http://example.de | Mix gives diverse TLDs

subdomains.text: Custom list of subdomains to randomly choose from. Use JSON list format. Leave empty for random subdomains or no subdomain
subdomains.example: ["api", "www", "cdn"] gives: http://api.example.com, http://www.example.com, http://cdn.example.com | Empty gives: http://example.com or http://random.example.com

scheme.text: URI protocol/scheme to use. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse URI schemes (http, https, ws, wss, etc.)
scheme.example: HTTPS: https://example.com/api/users?page=1 | HTTP: http://example.com/products | WS: ws://example.com/socket | Mix gives diverse schemes

tld_type.text: Top-level domain type to use. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' for diverse TLDs in your URIs
tld_type.example: GTLD: https://example.com/path | CCTLD: https://example.uk/path | Mix gives: .com, .org, .uk, .de, etc.

subdomains.text: Custom list of subdomains for the URI. Use JSON list format. Leave empty for automatic subdomain generation
subdomains.example: ["api", "v1", "staging"] gives: https://api.example.com/users, https://v1.example.com/data | Empty gives random or no subdomain

query_params_count.text: Number of query parameters to include in the URI (the ?key=value&key2=value2 part). Leave empty or set to 0 for no query parameters

code.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get country codes in different formats
code.example: Mix gives: US (A2), USA (A3), FIFA codes, etc.

fmt.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to generate both ISBN-10 and ISBN-13 formats

mask.text: Custom template for ISSN format. Use # for digits. Leave empty for standard ISSN format (####-####)
Custom template for ISSN format. Use # for digits. Leave empty for standard ISSN format (####-####)

fmt.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to generate both EAN-8 and EAN-13 formats

min_duration.text: Minimum duration value (must be a positive number and less than max)
min_duration.example: If duration_unit is 'hours' and min=1, max=10, generates durations between 1 and 10 hours

max_duration.text: Maximum duration value (must be greater than min duration)
max_duration.example: If duration_unit is 'days' and min=1, max=30, generates durations between 1 and 30 days

duration_unit.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get durations in different units
duration_unit.example: Mix gives: days, hours, minutes, seconds, etc.

dms.text: Toggle ON for degrees-minutes-seconds format, OFF for decimal degrees
Toggle ON for degrees-minutes-seconds format, OFF for decimal degrees
Toggle ON for degrees-minutes-seconds format, OFF for decimal degrees

abbr.text: Toggle ON for state abbreviations, OFF for full state names
abbr.example: OFF: California, Texas, New York | ON: CA, TX, NY

abbr.text: Toggle ON for province abbreviations, OFF for full province names
abbr.example: OFF: Ontario, Quebec, British Columbia | ON: ON, QC, BC

abbr.text: Toggle ON for company type abbreviations, OFF for full type names
abbr.example: OFF: Limited Liability Company, Corporation | ON: LLC, Corp

abbr.text: Toggle ON to include company type abbreviation in the name
abbr.example: OFF: Acme Industries, TechCorp | ON: Acme Industries LLC, TechCorp Inc

with_plus.text: Toggle ON to include '+' prefix in calling codes

mask.text: Template pattern for phone number generation. Use # for digits. Leave empty for locale-appropriate default phone format. This controls the exact format of generated phone numbers

placeholder.text: Character to use as placeholder for formatting separators in the phone number. Default is typically '-' or space
placeholder.example: '-' gives: 555-123-4567 | ' ' gives: 555 123 4567 | '.' gives: 555.123.4567 | Works with mask to create custom separators

formatted.text: Toggle ON for formatted phone numbers with dashes/parentheses

minimum.text: Minimum price value (must be a positive number and less than maximum)

maximum.text: Maximum price value (must be greater than minimum)

as_string.text: Toggle ON to return price as formatted string with currency symbol

minimum.text: Minimum BTC price value (must be 0 or greater and less than maximum)
minimum.example: 0.001 generates BTC prices starting from 0.001 BTC

maximum.text: Maximum BTC price value (must be greater than minimum)
maximum.example: 2.0 generates BTC prices up to 2.0 BTC

minimum.text: Minimum file size value (must be a positive number and less than maximum)
minimum.example: 1 generates file sizes starting from 1 kB (e.g., 1 kB, 5 kB, 10 kB)

maximum.text: Maximum file size value (must be greater than minimum)
maximum.example: 100 generates file sizes up to 100 kB (e.g., 56 kB, 78 kB, 95 kB)

words_count.text: Number of words in each sentence

with_punctuation.text: Toggle ON to add proper punctuation at the end of sentences
with_punctuation.example: OFF: This is a sentence | ON: This is a sentence.

sentences_count.text: Number of sentences in each paragraph

length.text: Length of the word to generate

capitalize.text: Toggle ON to capitalize the first letter of the word

safe.text: Toggle ON for web-safe colors only, OFF for any hex color

precision.text: Number of decimal places for matrix values

formatted.text: Toggle ON for formatted SSN with dashes

plus4.text: Toggle ON to include ZIP+4 extended code

rh.text: Toggle ON to include Rh factor in blood type
rh.example: OFF: A, B, AB, O | ON: A+, B-, AB+, O-

category.text: Specific occupation category to generate from

with_port.text: Toggle ON to include port number with IP address

compressed.text: Toggle ON for compressed IPv6 format (shorter)

separator.text: Character to separate MAC address octets

platform.text: Operating system/platform for the user agent

safe_only.text: Toggle ON for safe HTTP methods only (GET, HEAD, OPTIONS)
safe_only.example: OFF: includes POST, PUT, DELETE | ON: GET, HEAD, OPTIONS only

category.example: 1xx Info, 2xx Success, 3xx Redirect, 4xx Client Error, 5xx Server Error

port_range.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get ports from all ranges

locale.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse locale codes
locale.example: Mix gives: en_US, fr_FR, de_DE, ja_JP, es_ES, etc.

iso_format.text: Toggle ON for ISO 4217 currency codes, OFF for currency symbols
iso_format.example: OFF: $, ‚Ç¨, ¬£, ¬• | ON: USD, EUR, GBP, JPY

minimum.text: Minimum weight value in kilograms. Must be a positive number and less than maximum. Generates realistic human body weights
minimum.example: 40 for lightweight/children (40-100 kg range) | 50 for average adults (50-90 kg) | 60 for heavier range (60-120 kg) | Used for: patient records, fitness apps, health databases

maximum.text: Maximum weight value in kilograms. Must be greater than minimum. Sets the upper limit for generated weights
maximum.example: 100 with min=50 gives typical adult range (50-100 kg) | 120 with min=60 gives broader range | 90 with min=50 gives moderate range (50-90 kg)

name_only.text: Toggle ON to return only element name, OFF for full details
Toggle ON to return only planet name, OFF for full details

as_hex.text: Toggle ON to return color as hex code, OFF for color name
as_hex.example: OFF: Red, Blue, Green, Yellow | ON: #FF0000, #0000FF, #00FF00, #FFFF00

title_type.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse title types
title_type.example: Mix gives: Mr., Mrs., Ms., Dr., Prof., etc.

length.text: Number of nucleotide base pairs in the DNA sequence. Default is 10. DNA uses 4 bases: A (Adenine), T (Thymine), G (Guanine), C (Cytosine)
length.example: 10 gives: ATGCGTACGA (10 base pairs) | 20 gives: ATGCGTACGAATGCGTACGA (20 base pairs) | 50 gives longer sequences | 100+ for gene-like sequences | Used for: genetic testing, bioinformatics, molecular biology simulations

length.text: Number of nucleotide bases in the RNA sequence. Default is 10. RNA uses 4 bases: A (Adenine), U (Uracil), G (Guanine), C (Cytosine). Note: RNA uses U instead of T
length.example: 10 gives: AUGCGUACGA (10 bases) | 20 gives: AUGCGUACGAAUGCGUACGA (20 bases) | 50 gives longer sequences | 100+ for mRNA-like sequences | Used for: transcription studies, RNA research, molecular biology

name.text: Type of measurement unit to generate. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse units across all physical quantities (mass, length, temperature, energy, etc.)
name.example: MASS: gram (gr) | TEMPERATURE: Celsius (¬∞C) | FORCE: newton (N) | ENERGY: joule (J) | FREQUENCY: hertz (Hz) | Mix gives diverse units from all categories

symbol.text: Toggle ON to return unit symbol only, OFF to return full unit name with symbol
symbol.example: OFF: gram (gr), Celsius (¬∞C), newton (N), joule (J) | ON: gr, ¬∞C, N, J (symbols only)

measure_unit.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse measurement units
measure_unit.example: Mix gives: meters, kilograms, liters, celsius, etc.

sign.text: Sign of the metric prefix (positive or negative powers of 10). Choose 'Mix All (Random)' for both positive and negative prefixes
sign.example: POSITIVE: kilo (k, 10¬≥), mega (M, 10‚Å∂), giga (G, 10‚Åπ) | NEGATIVE: milli (m, 10‚Åª¬≥), micro (Œº, 10‚Åª‚Å∂), nano (n, 10‚Åª‚Åπ) | Mix gives both positive and negative prefixes

symbol.text: Toggle ON to return prefix symbol only, OFF to return full prefix name with symbol
symbol.example: OFF: kilo (k), mega (M), milli (m), micro (Œº) | ON: k, M, m, Œº (symbols only)

dsn_type.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get different database DSN types
dsn_type.example: Mix gives: PostgreSQL, MySQL, MongoDB, Redis, etc.

0.text: üåê Don't panic! These numbers (0, 1, 2, 3...) are OPTIONAL custom TLD filters. You can safely LEAVE THEM ALL EMPTY to generate random top-level domains (.com, .org, .net, etc.). Only fill them if you want to specify particular TLDs to randomly choose from.
0.example: Empty (recommended): generates random .com, .org, .uk, .de, etc. | Fill 0='com', 1='org': only generates .com or .org | Fill 0='uk', 1='de', 2='fr': only UK, German, or French domains

1.text: Second custom TLD option (optional). Leave empty for automatic random TLD generation.
1.example: If 0='com' and 1='net': randomly chooses between .com and .net

2.text: Third custom TLD option (optional). Only use if you want to limit TLDs to specific choices.

3.text: Fourth custom TLD option (optional). Most users don't need to fill this.
3.example: Adding more custom TLD choices like: uk, de, fr, jp

4.text: Fifth custom TLD option (optional). Use only if you need many specific TLD choices.
4.example: Building a custom list of allowed TLDs for your use case

5.text: Sixth custom TLD option (optional). Rarely needed - for extensive custom TLD lists.

6.text: Seventh custom TLD option (optional). Advanced use only.

tld_type.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get diverse top-level domains

port_range.text: Choose 'Mix All (Random)' to get ports from all ranges
port_range.example: Mix gives various port numbers from different ranges

field.text: Specific professional field to generate from
Industry field for the job title

abbr.text: Toggle ON for degree abbreviations, OFF for full degree names
abbr.example: OFF: Bachelor of Science, Master of Arts, Doctor of Philosophy | ON: B.S., M.A., Ph.D.

abbr.text: Toggle ON to include university abbreviation
abbr.example: OFF: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Stanford University | ON: MIT, Stanford

formatted.text: Toggle ON for formatted IBAN with spaces
Toggle ON for formatted BIC/SWIFT code

symbol.text: Toggle ON to include cryptocurrency symbol

exchange.text: Stock exchange to generate ticker from

formatted.text: Toggle ON for formatted IMEI with dashes

major_only.text: Toggle ON to generate only major world religions
major_only.example: OFF: includes all religions | ON: Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, etc.

iso_code.text: Toggle ON for ISO 639-1 language codes, OFF for language names
iso_code.example: OFF: English, Spanish, French, German, Japanese | ON: en, es, fr, de, ja

gender_specific.text: Toggle ON for gender-specific nationality terms (in some languages)

full.text: Toggle ON for full address including apartment/suite numbers
full.example: OFF: 123 Main St | ON: 123 Main St, Apt 4B

with_suffix.text: Toggle ON to include street suffix (St, Ave, Blvd)

code.text: Toggle ON for continent codes (2-letter), OFF for full continent names
code.example: OFF: Antarctica, Africa, Europe, Asia | ON: AN, AF, EU, AS

iso_code.text: Toggle ON for ISO country codes (2-letter), OFF for full country names
iso_code.example: OFF: United States, Germany, Japan | ON: US, DE, JP

with_state.text: Toggle ON to include state/province with city name
with_state.example: OFF: New York | ON: New York, NY

formatted.text: Toggle ON for formatted postal codes with dashes

tld_type.text: Top-level domain type to use for hostname generation. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' for diverse TLDs
tld_type.example: CCTLD: example.uk, example.de | GTLD: example.com, example.org | GEOTLD: example.asia, example.africa | Mix gives diverse TLDs across all types

subdomains.text: Custom list of subdomains to randomly choose from. Use JSON list format. Leave empty for no subdomain or random subdomain

with_subdomain.text: Toggle ON to include random subdomain

width.text: Image width in pixels. This generates a URL to a stock image with your specified width. Useful for testing image displays, galleries, or responsive designs.
width.example: 800 gives URLs like: https://picsum.photos/800/600 | 1920 gives full HD width images | 400 gives smaller thumbnail-sized images

height.text: Image height in pixels. Combined with width, this creates URLs for stock images at your exact dimensions. Perfect for testing image layouts and aspect ratios.
height.example: 600 with width=800 gives 800√ó600 images | 1080 with width=1920 gives full HD 1920√ó1080 images | 300 with width=400 gives small 400√ó300 thumbnails

keywords.text: Optional list of keywords to filter stock images by topic/theme. Use JSON list format. Leave empty for random images, or specify keywords to get relevant images.
keywords.example: ["nature", "landscape"] gives nature/landscape images | ["business", "office"] gives business-themed images | ["food", "cooking"] gives food/cooking images | Empty gives random diverse images

parts_count.text: Number of words in the URL slug

0.text: üìÅ Don't panic! These numbers (0, 1, 2, 3...) are path segments - each number represents a level in the URL path. You can leave them empty to generate random paths, or fill specific ones to customize your path structure.

1.text: Second level of the path (optional). Leave empty for random generation or specify a custom segment.

2.text: Third level of the path (optional). Continue building your custom path structure.

3.text: Fourth level of the path (optional). Each number adds another segment to your URL path.

4.text: Fifth level of the path (optional). You can create paths as deep as needed for your use case.

5.text: Sixth level of the path (optional). Perfect for complex API structures or deep file paths.

6.text: Seventh level of the path (optional). Great for nested resources or hierarchical structures.

7.text: Eighth level of the path (optional). For very deep path structures when needed.

length.text: Number of key-value pairs to generate in the query parameters dictionary. This controls how many parameters will be included in your URL query string.
Number of query parameters to generate in the URL query string format

common_only.text: Toggle ON to generate only well-known ports (80, 443, 8080, etc.)

success_only.text: Toggle ON to generate only successful HTTP codes (2xx)

mime_type.text: MIME type category for Content-Type headers. Choose 'Mix All (Random)' for diverse content types
mime_type.example: APPLICATION: application/json, application/xml, application/pdf | IMAGE: image/jpeg, image/png, image/gif | TEXT: text/html, text/plain, text/css | AUDIO: audio/mpeg, audio/wav | VIDEO: video/mp4, video/webm

common_only.text: Toggle ON to generate only commonly used Content-Type headers
common_only.example: OFF: any content type | ON: text/html, application/json, image/png, text/plain, application/xml

private_only.text: Toggle ON to generate private IP addresses only

numeric.text: Toggle ON for numeric month, OFF for month name
numeric.example: OFF: January, February, March, December | ON: 01, 02, 03, 12

abbr.text: Toggle ON for abbreviated month names
abbr.example: OFF: January, February, September, December | ON: Jan, Feb, Sep, Dec

numeric.text: Toggle ON for numeric day (1-7), OFF for day name
numeric.example: OFF: Monday, Tuesday, Friday, Sunday | ON: 1, 2, 5, 7

abbr.text: Toggle ON for abbreviated day names
abbr.example: OFF: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Sunday | ON: Mon, Tue, Wed, Sun

start.text: Starting year for week date generation
start.example: 2017 generates week numbers from year 2017 onwards (e.g., 2017-W15, 2018-W32)

end.text: Ending year for week date generation
end.example: 2025 generates week numbers up to year 2025 (e.g., 2024-W45, 2025-W10)

with_name.text: Toggle ON to include timezone name with offset

formatted.text: Toggle ON for formatted bank account with dashes/spaces

validated.text: Toggle ON to generate validated routing numbers only
validated.example: OFF: any 9 digits | ON: valid checksum routing numbers

length.text: Length of CVV code (3 or 4 digits)

future_only.text: Toggle ON to generate only future expiration dates
future_only.example: OFF: any date | ON: dates after today

minimum.text: Minimum year for credit card expiration date. Represents years from 2000 (e.g., 16 = 2016, 25 = 2025). Must be less than maximum
minimum.example: 16: generates dates from 2016 onwards | 22: generates dates from 2022 onwards | 25: generates dates from 2025 onwards | Recommended: Use current year or later for realistic data

maximum.text: Maximum year for credit card expiration date. Represents years from 2000 (e.g., 16 = 2016, 25 = 2025). Must be greater than minimum
maximum.example: 25: generates dates up to 2025 | 30: generates dates up to 2030 | 35: generates dates up to 2035 | Recommended: Use 5-10 years from current year for realistic range

full_name.text: Toggle ON for full vehicle name with make, model, and year

formatted.text: Toggle ON for formatted VIN with dashes

celsius.text: Toggle ON for Celsius, OFF for Fahrenheit
Toggle ON for Celsius, OFF for Fahrenheit

precision.text: Number of decimal places for coordinate precision

with_symbol.text: Toggle ON to include % symbol with the number

decimal.text: Toggle ON to allow decimal ratings

mask.text: Template pattern for identifier generation. Use special characters: # for digits, @ for letters, * for any alphanumeric. This creates custom ID formats for people/users
mask.example: Empty: random alphanumeric ID | ####-####: 1234-5678 | ID-######: ID-123456 | @@-####: AB-1234 (2 letters + 4 digits) | USR*******: USR12ab34cd (prefix + 8 alphanumeric)

prefix.text: Prefix to add before the identifier

hex.text: Toggle ON for hexadecimal token, OFF for alphanumeric

entropy.text: Number of random bytes to generate (must be 0 or positive). Higher values create longer, more secure tokens
entropy.example: 16 generates 16 bytes of random data, 32 generates 32 bytes

entropy.text: Number of random bytes (must be 0 or positive). Output will be twice this length in hex characters
entropy.example: 16 generates 32 hex characters, 32 generates 64 hex characters

entropy.text: Number of random bytes (must be 0 or positive). Creates URL-safe base64 encoded tokens
